title: Ticket #2848: document Even More sinful strings
description:
Nowhere in the manual is there mention of the more sinful format of an IP address such as 
<a.b.c.d:port?sock=URLencodedstuff>
like 
<128.104.100.43:9618?sock=29580_93e1_2>

Since this might be specified anywhere an IP address identifies a daemon, it should be documented.
remarks:
2012-Jun-13 12:42:12 by danb:
Hi Karen,

The general form for IPv4 is <IP:port?param1=value1&param2=value2&param3=value3&...>

Alan can describe the IPv6 format.

The parameters and values are url-encoded. This means any special character is encoded with % followed by two hexidecimal digits specifying the ascii value. Special characters are any non-alphanumeric character.

Parameters currently recognized by Condor are:

* CCBID - contact information for forming a CCB connection to this daemon in form: IP:port#ID where IP:port is the address of the CCB server and ID is a unique identifier for this daemon within that server. More than one IP:port#ID may be specified if the daemon is registered with more than one CCB server. The list is space-separated.

* PrivNet - name of daemon's private network (configured with PRIVATE_NETWORK_NAME)

* sock - name of shared-port named socket for this daemon

* PrivAddr - daemon's private address in form IP:port

2012-Jun-15 10:48:10 by smoler:
Not sure that I get the details of CCBID well enough, as a list. Assuming that it is a list, would this be an example (horribly incorrect) that correctly implements the space-separated values? I have no idea of what the ID part is, so I just made up integer values. 

  505.123.456.222:5283?CCBID=505.111.222.333:400#88 505.122.233.344:400#99 505.133.244.355:400#77

2012-Jun-15 11:00:03 by danb:
Yes, the example of a CCBID list looks good, except the spaces would be urlencoded as %20 rather than appearing as literal spaces.
2012-Aug-23 14:09:08 by zmiller:
